Award.AbstractNarration:
This award funds the participation of undergraduate students in the American Economic Association Summer Training Program. The goal of the AEASTP is to help talented undergraduate students learn skills and conduct research in economics in preparation for studies at the doctoral level. The program is in open to all qualified students regardless of race, ethnicity, or gender. Organizers make special efforts to recruit students from groups under-represented in the economics profession. The program combines a research experience with intensive coursework and career mentoring. The program is currently conducted by the University of New Mexico.

The road to successful Ph.D. study in economics can be a rocky one, especially for students coming from minority-serving institutions and institutions that do not have a strong research focus. Obstacles include undergraduate economics curricula that are often oriented towards the most popular student career goal - business - than Ph.D. study, a lack of familiarity with the application process, and financial limitations. One consequence is that several important demographic groups are under-represented on economics faculties in the U.S. . AEASTP addresses these roadblocks in a direct way.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The primary goal of this project was to provide opportunities for research and improve the skills of members from under-represented groups in order to improve their access to or retention in research, teaching or other related professional activities in the field of economics.  In particular, the aim is to increase the number of students who enter into and successfully complete PhD programs in economics and related fields.

A total of 45 students from all over the United States participated in this program in the summers of 2015 and 2016, with three students participating in both summers—completing a newly introduced advanced level in the summer of 2016. Students received instruction in microeconomic theory, econometrics, mathematical methods and research methods, with students engaging in original research projects that were presented at a conference at the conclusion of the program.

Student progress was demonstrated through regular examinations and the research presentations were judged by a wide-ranging jury made up of faculty and graduate students in economics from across the US. Students’ abilities and skills improved markedly in the course of the summer as demonstrated by performance on exams and homework assignments. Post-program surveys have demonstrated students’ strong interests in pursuing further training and education on a path towards enrolling in graduate programs. Most students have the ultimate objective to pursue a research career and they view the program as a critical step in that direction. At least four of the student-participants are already enrolled in graduate programs, and others are taking concrete steps to ready themselves for this step.
